awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the National Academy of Science to implement a Roundtable on Global Science Diplomacy to advance knowledge at the intersection of science and policy with the goal of sustained U.S. leadership in science diplomacy. Science diplomacy has emerged as a critical concept for discussions within the scientific and foreign policy communities. The United States has been a leader both at the governmental and non-governmental levels. In recent years, unfortunately, some efforts within the United States have decreased, especially with the decrease in activity and focus within the AAAS Center for Science Diplomacy. At a time when many national challenges are intrinsically linked to global developments, and global challenges require U.S. leadership science diplomacy, including accessing knowledge networks, is critical to achieving goals and in turn, preserving the welfare of the U.S. The Roundtable seeks to reinforce U.S. expertise and leadership in this space, promote young scientists and future generations to continue this important work, and ensure beneficial U.S. interaction with the growing number of science diplomacy networks.The Roundtable also provides an opportunity to investigate the role of funding agencies in science diplomacy especially as it relates to multilateral and global networks and how best to leverage and strengthen networks. It is also an opportunity for agencies to further their international reach, highlight their own innovative programs, and learn from other innovative initiatives around the world.

Roundtable discussions will be structured to catalyze activities such as topical workshops within NASEM as well as activities, projects, and programs to be pursued by others. Workshop topics include a focus on next generation talent, involving NASEM's early-career STEM leader initiative, New Voices; regional opportunities within key countries as identified through discussions with the U.S. government;
and assessing progress since the 1999 National Academies report on science in foreign policy to map future opportunities in this space.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Roundtable on Global Science Diplomacy convenes experts and practitioners from government, academia, and international organizations to utilize this neutral, informal channel to promote science diplomacy as a tool in addressing global challenges, informing global policy making and building societal relationships. There is a special focus on developing and mobilizing the next generation of science diplomats. The goals of the Roundtable are to:

  • Highlight promising practices and programs for increasing the input of science and technology into the conduct of foreign policy and international affairs;
  • Conduct discussions on how science diplomacy can help deal successfully with national and global challenges;
  • Investigate policy approaches to make international science and technology collaboration easier and more effective;
  • Increase learning from examples of successes and failures to connect science to diplomacy within different scientific and diplomatic systems;
  • Investigate approaches for preparing the next generation of science diplomats;
  • Identify areas where science cooperation can provide a means of transcending traditional diplomatic tensions; and
  • Investigate approaches for engaging science communities in failed and failing states.

The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM) appointed a group of 35 members representing government, academia, and the public and private sector to help address the Roundtable goals listed above.

The Roundtable held a virtual meeting on April 23, 2020 to discuss the COVID-19 pandemic and opportunities for Roundtable members to effectively engage their expertise in crucial discussions and partnerships that aim to address gaps in the science-policy interface.

The objectives of the meeting were to:

  • Provide a means for representatives of government, industry, academia and other stakeholder groups to discuss the COVID-19 pandemic within the context of science diplomacy.
  • Suggest and discuss opportunities for roundtable member action in the short term.
  • Discuss and develop possible initiatives around the U.S. response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Six working groups were formed focused on areas of priority as determined by the members and designed to explore additional activities for the Roundtable. These working groups are: Track II Dialogues, opportunities and challenges at universities; international organizations; research barriers and gaps; combatting misinformation and engaging networks; and engaging the private sector. These working groups convened in June 2020 to refine ideas for potential activities, topics for the agenda of future Roundtable meetings, and additional workshops. Working groups identified several short-term and long-term ideas, including opportunities for collaboration outside the Roundtable forum.

These included:

  • Track II Dialogues: with China, the UK, Europe, Japan, Australia, Brazil, India, and others to rebuild relationships and strengthen our science advisory ecosystems; but also ?traditional? science diplomacy countries like Iran, Cuba, Russia, and North Korea.
  • Opportunities and challenges at universities: developing guidelines and models for new programs on training foreign relations students in science topics; studying a less perturbed Earth; impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on internationalization strategies of universities.
  • International organizations: strengthening, rethinking models, but also strengthening the science-policy interface in these organizations.
  • Research barriers and gaps: identify disruption of networks and barriers to effective collaboration; strengthen connections within the global scientific community working on the novel coronavirus.
  • Combat misinformation and engage existing networks for action.
  • Engage the private sector: including international companies that have international supply chains and engage in science, technology, and innovation across the world. 

The Roundtable virtual meeting discussions proposed additional activities, such as topical workshops within NASEM as well as additional activities, projects, and programs to be pursued by others. Two workshops were organized under the auspices of the Roundtable, one in September 2020 and another in March 2021. These are described in the next section of this report.

Planning for the next meeting of the Roundtable occurred from May-September. There are three sessions planned for December 2021, (1) the role of technology in delivering services to displaced peoples, (2) verifiable COVID-19 credentials for international travel, and (3) current U.S. government science diplomacy initiatives.

Workshops under the auspices of the Roundtable on Global Science Diplomacy

The first workshop, "Science Technology, and Health Capabilities Within the Department of State and USAID at an Inflection Point," was held in September 2020 and focused on the role of science, technology, and health at the U.S. Department of State and USAID, taking into account the changing science and technology and geopolitical landscape.

The second workshop, "Science Diplomacy to Promote and Strengthen Research and International Cooperation," was held in March 2021 and focused on identifying different mechanisms and approaches for investigating the links between international basic research cooperation in the context of science diplomacy, as well as opportunities for the Global Research Council and funder communities to work together.
